fracas-problems.comment: Translation of the FraCaS test suite into Farsi(Persian) as spoken in Iran by M.Reza Khezri & Mahsa Salimy , 2012-08-15

Legends: caus : Causative verb subj : Subjunctive verb 3sg : 3rd person, singular 3pl : 3rd person. plural question word : the word ‘aya’ which is used at the beginning of yes/no questions in Farsi n-adj connector : noun adjective connector Relates an adjective to the noun it is describing Example : Both commissioners used to be leading businessmen. both member of commission previously businessman [n-adj connector] leading were[3pl] object marker -> determines the objective role of a noun in a sentence & comes after the object of a sentence Example : Jones saw Smith. Jones Smith [object marker] saw

p.script: یک ایتالیایی بزرگترین تِنورِ جهان شد
p.translit: yek italiayi bozorgtarin tenor e jahan shod.
p.morph: An Italian greatest tenor of world became
p.english: An Italian became the world's greatest tenor.

q.script: آیا یک ایتالیایی وجود داشت که بزرگترین تِنورِ جهان بِشود؟
q.translit: Aya yek italiayi vojood dasht ke bozorgtarin tenor e jahan beshavad?
q.morph: Question-word one Italian there was who[that] greatest tenor of world become[subj 3sg] ?
q.english: Was there an Italian who became the world's greatest tenor?

h.script: یک ایتالیایی وجود داشت که بزرگترین تِنورِ جهان شد
h.translit: yek italiayi vojood-dasht ke bozorgtarin tenor e jahan shod.
h.morph: an Italian there-was[3sg] who[that] greatest tenor of world became[3sg]
h.english: There was an Italian who became the world's greatest tenor.

p.script: هر مرد ایتالیایی می خواهد که یک تِنورِ بزرگ باشد
p.translit: har mard e italiayi mikhahad ke yek tenor e bozorg bashad.
p.morph: every man [n-adj connector] Italian wants to a tenor [n-adj connector] great be[subj 3sg]
p.english: Every Italian man wants to be a great tenor.

p.translit: bazi az mardha ye italiayi tenorha ye bozorgi hastand.

p.english: Some Italian men are great tenors.

problem.note:
In Farsi the answer would be No,because the sentence in h means there were 2 contracts and Smith and Jones both signed them.
If the hypothesis was " Smith and Jones Signed two different contracts" then the answer would be yes.

fracas-problems.comment: In the examples below we make the assumption (unless otherwise indicated) that there is no context beyond that provided by the mini-discourse. This is so that we can do away with explicit co-indexing of pronouns with their antecedents, on the grounds that context will provide only (or sometimes a strictly limited number) of possible antecedents.

fracas-problems.comment: Due to the heavy domain dependence of functional (or better perhaps, relational) anaphora, it is hard to state general inferences that don't assume considerable background knowledge unless this is given explicitly.

problem.note:
Since in Farsi there is no definite article, relating these sentences to each other is not as obvious as in the English version.
Ususally to make a noun like "cover page" definite in Farsi , a pronoun is used so that it would have a meening as follows :
"Smith signed its cover page." where "its" refers to the cover page of R-95-103 report.

fracas-problems.comment:
In nearly all cases the inferences presented here have conclusions that are simply reconstructions of the ellided constituent. Unfortunately, an inference test suite is not well suited to illustrating prohibitions on ellipsis resolution. For example, an ill-formed discourse like
John was in Paris yesterday. *So did Bill.
doesn't even get as far as supporting any inferences.

fracas-problems.comment: Note that the first sentence in (175) and (176) is syntactically ambiguous, depending on whether the conjunctive clause conjoins with the main or subordinate clause of "John said Mary wrote a report". In (177) the conjunctive clause unambiguously conjoins with the subordinate clause, and only one interpretation of the ellipsis is possible. This appears to indicate that the antecedent clause to a VP ellipsis must be adjacent to the elliptical clause. However, as the examples below show, this is not correct.

fracas-problems.comment: Other configurational effects of the kinds illustrated in Deliverable 7 are hard to exemplify using inference suites.
The following inferences illustrate differences between strict and sloppy interpretations of anaphors in elliptical clauses.

fracas-problems.comment: The inferences below carve up adjectives into (a by no means exhaustive) cross-cutting set of dimensions. Typical inferences are given for example adjectives.

Affirmative adjectives map the denotation of the predicate they modify onto a subset of the denotation. So for example, an old man is a man. Most adjectives are affirmative, but a few like former and fake are not. Given that someone is a former student, one cannot conclude that they are now a student. But it is not entirely clear whether one can conclude that they are not now a student ... they may have become one again.

fracas-problems.comment: Gradable adjectives (e.g. big, small) usually assume some form of comparison class (i.e. "big for an N"). But some others do not e.g. four-legged, or the adjectival phrase ten foot long. Adjectives not requiring a comparison class permit straightforward predication without reference to a nominal property providing a comparison class: a ten foot long alligator is ten foot long.

problem.note:
In farsi the adjective "clever" rather describes the general power of someone's brain in understanding things.
Therefor John is a clever person than Bill regardless of their profession.

fracas-problems.comment: Note that both intensional and extensional comparison class adjectives support comparatives.

Comparison class adjectives can sometimes pick up a default comparison class from the subject NP. For example, knowing that Kim is a person provides a default scale for assessing cleverness in people. If Kim were known to be a dog, the assessment scale would be different.

problem.note:
According to the first premise pc-6082 and ITEL-XZ are equally fast. Therefor if PC-6082 is fast then the ITEL-XZ is
fast as well and the answer is "Yes" .

fracas-problems.comment: Inferences (233)-(235) are similar to (230)-(232). Note however, that if "APCOM" can be interpreted as referring to a particular order (e.g. "the APCOM contract"), as it can in (233), the sentence ITEL won more orders than APCOM is ambiguous between a reading like that in (230)-(232), and one where ITEL won more than just the APCOM order ... see (236)

problem.note: In Farsi, such sentences which have two verbs, one of the verbs mostly turns to Causative form which describes the state of an action. The Causative phrase is a dependent clause which is marked by the phrase ‘inke (that)’

problem.note: In Farsi, the past tense of a verb describes Completion of an action e.g. someone has started and has finished swimming. Here, unlike the English sentence, the verb ‘shena kard (Swam)' implies the action of swimming from the beginning till the end. Therefore, if X happens before Y, Y happens after X.

p.script: اسمیت دید که جونز قرارداد را امضا کرد

p.english: Smith saw Jones sign the contract.

p.script: اگر جونز قرارداد را امضا کرد, قلبش می تپید
